Name: Dinotefuran
Description: Dinotefuran is a member of oxolanes. It has a role as a neonicotinoid insectide. It is functionally related to a 2-nitroguanidine.

plant_translocations.content: Pesticides are essential for protecting agricultural products and increasing productivity, but their frequent use leads to residue accumulation in the environment, which can be absorbed by plants and translocated to edible parts. This study investigated the uptake of soil-applied dinotefuran and three major metabolites by lettuce and celery from previous season's applications and analyzed their residues in soil and consumable parts. Dinotefuran was applied to soil at intervals of 30 and 60 days before planting. Residue levels of dinotefuran and its metabolites in mature lettuce leaves and celery shoots, as well as soil samples at various stages, were estimated. The uptake of dinotefuran by lettuce and celery ranged between 23.8% and 28% and between 51.73% and 53.06%, respectively. The half-lives of dinotefuran in lettuce soil ranged from 1.33 to 1.54 days for PBI-30 and 0.91 to 2.16 days for PBI-60, while in celery soil, they ranged from 0.9 to 1.47 days for PBI-30 and 0.79 to 1.65 days for PBI-60. Residues were below Korean MRLs in most samples, indicating negligible risk. The study recommends planting the next crop at least 60 days after harvesting the first crop to minimize pesticide residue risks.
plant_translocations.reference: Ham, H. J., Choi, J. Y., Jo, Y. J., Sardar, S. W., Ishag, A. E. S. A., Abdelbagi, A. O., & Hur, J. H. (2022). Residues and uptake of soil-applied dinotefuran by lettuce (Lactuca sativa L.) and celery (Apium graveolens L.). Agriculture, 12(9), 1443.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Experiments were conducted in greenhouses at Pyeongtaek (37.0555191°N, 126.154296°E) and Chuncheon (37.9366547°N, 127.782659°E), South Korea, on sandy soils with 2.63-5.16% organic matter, pH 5.5-6.5, CEC 13.31-18.49 cmolc/kg.
method.Chemical Preparation: Dinotefuran analytical standard (98.7% purity) was used along with metabolite standards 1-methyl-2-nitroguanidine (MNG, 100% pure), 1-methyl-3-(tetrahydro-3-furylmethyl) urea (UF, 99.8% pure), and 1-methyl-3-(tetrahydro-3-furylmethyl) guanidium dihydrogen (DN, 98.5% pure).
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Dinotefuran was thoroughly mixed with control soil at 90 g/6 kg rate, spread over subplots, and immediately irrigated to incorporate into soil following OECD rotational crop guidelines. Plants were grown 30 and 60 days after soil treatment.
method.Other Information: Lettuce and celery crops were sampled at 50% (21 days for lettuce, 45 days for celery) and 100% maturity (28 days for lettuce, 75 days for celery) using RDA harvest method. Control untreated samples were also collected at same intervals. Samples were kept cool at 18°C until residue analysis. Replication details were not provided.

plant_translocations.content: We conducted uptake experiments with 12 different organic chemicals using 16 plant species and observed variations in their ability to take up and translocate these chemicals. The shoot and root concentrations of each chemical varied among the plant species. Root concentration factor values increased with an increasing log of the n-octanol-water partition coefficient (log Kow) of the organic chemicals, suggesting that root concentrations may be predicted to some extent based on log Kow. Root-to-shoot translocation was also related to log Kow, as the shoot-to-root concentration ratio decreased with increasing log Kow. However, the relationship between shoot concentration factor value and log Kow was not clear and differed among plant species.
plant_translocations.reference: Namiki, S., Otani, T., Motoki, Y., Seike, N., & Iwafune, T. (2018). Differential uptake and translocation of organic chemicals by several plant species from soil. Journal of pesticide science, 43(2), 96-107.

method.Test Plant: Hordeum distichon, Zea mays L., Glycine max Merrill, Phaseolus vulgaris L., Brassica oleracea L. var. capitata, Brassica rapa L. war. peruviridis, Chrysanthemum coronarium L., Lactuca sativa L., Allissms wakegi Araki, Apium graveolens L. war. dulce, Solanum lycopersicum Mill., Capsicum grossism, Cucumtis sativis L., Cucurbita maxima Duch., Spinacia oleracea L., and Beta vulgaris L. var. cicla.
method.Plant Grown Condition: Seeds germinated in nursery soil in growth chamber at 20°C, 14:10 hr light:dark cycle. Seedlings transplanted at 7-28 days into test soil pots and grown for 21 more days under same conditions. Soil moisture maintained at 50-70% water holding capacity (WHC).
method.Chemical Preparation: 12 organic chemicals (10 pesticides, β-HCH, dieldrin) with log Kow -0.6 to 5 dissolved in acetone at 50 mg/L. 1 L mixture added to 278g Celite powder, acetone evaporated leaving 92.6-133.6 μg/g of each chemical on Celite.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 450g uncontaminated soil mixed with 5g chemical-loaded Celite in 600 mL pots. Fertilized with chemical fertilizer and dolomite. Final concentrations ranged 81.0-129.7 μg/pot.
method.Other Information: Plants grown to obtain 1-2g root dry weight per species. At 21 days, shoots and roots harvested, fresh weights measured, divided into subsamples to determine moisture content and chemical concentrations.
